entries.title: Berkshire May Have Left $50 Billion on Table. Apple Is Why.
entries.snippet:
Warren Buffett’s decision to sell a significant portion of Apple stock may have cost Berkshire Hathaway approximately $50 billion in unrealized gains, according to Barron’s. Between 2016 and 2018, Berkshire acquired around 1 billion shares of Apple at an average price of $35. Most of the holding was sold in 2024 and 2025 at an estimated average price of $185, significantly below Apple’s current price of $262.24. By June 30, 2025, Berkshire’s Apple holdings had fallen to 280 million shares from 906 million at the end of 2023.

The sale generated roughly $96 billion in pretax gains but also resulted in nearly $20 billion in corporate income tax, lowering net proceeds to around $155 per share. Buffett cited concern over higher corporate taxes and the large size of the Apple stake as reasons for the sale. Some speculate he also aimed to strengthen Berkshire’s cash position, which stood at over $330 billion mid-2025, ahead of his retirement.

Apple was previously described by Buffett as a “pillar” of Berkshire’s value, suggesting it would be a long-term holding. The Apple sale, along with similar moves involving Bank of America, appears to have negatively impacted Berkshire’s performance, with its stock up 9% in 2025 versus the S&P 500’s 16%.

entries.title: Berkshire Sold 25% of Its Apple Stock in the Third Quarter
entries.snippet: In the third quarter of 2024, Berkshire Hathaway sold 100 million shares of Apple, reducing its stake by 25% to 300 million shares. This follows a nearly 50% reduction in the second quarter, cutting the investment down from its peak of 905 million shares at the start of the year. The decision appears to be driven by Apple’s high valuation—trading at 30 times expected earnings—and a strategic rebalancing of Berkshire's portfolio, where Apple had previously comprised about 45%. Despite the sales, Apple remains Berkshire’s largest equity holding, now worth approximately $67 billion, accounting for under 25% of its $300 billion portfolio. The Apple shares were originally purchased at about $35 each between 2016 and 2018, and with the stock closing at $222.91 on the last trading day of the quarter, Berkshire has realized massive gains, estimated between $15 to $20 billion on the Apple sales alone. Cumulatively in 2024, the company reported $76.5 billion in investment gains, mostly from Apple. CEO Warren Buffett previously indicated Apple would likely remain Berkshire’s largest holding by year-end.

entries.title: Warren Buffett hails Tim Cook for making Berkshire more money than he has — after selling two-thirds of his Apple stake
entries.snippet: At Berkshire Hathaway's 2025 annual meeting, Warren Buffett praised Apple CEO Tim Cook, calling him a "one-of-a-kind leader" and crediting him for significantly increasing Berkshire's wealth. Buffett noted that although Berkshire invested around $35 billion in Apple from 2016 to 2018, its value had risen to $173 billion by the end of 2023, largely due to Cook's leadership. Despite selling approximately two-thirds of its Apple holdings in 2024, retaining 300 million shares worth around $62 billion, Buffett lauded Cook's unmatched ability to grow the company. He highlighted that while Steve Jobs uniquely created Apple, only Cook could have developed it to its current stature. Under Cook’s leadership since 2011, Apple’s stock rose from under $15 to $205, elevating the company’s market capitalization to over $3 trillion.

entries.title: Buffett's Berkshire sells one-third of VeriSign stake for $1.23 billion
entries.snippet: Berkshire Hathaway has sold approximately one-third of its stake in VeriSign, an internet infrastructure and domain name registry company, for $1.23 billion. The sale involved 4.3 million shares at $285 each, reducing Berkshire's ownership from 14.2% to 9.6%. VeriSign noted the sale was intended to reduce Berkshire's stake below the 10% threshold, which triggers regulatory obligations. The price per share reflected a 6.9% discount from VeriSign’s last closing price of $305.98, and the stock dropped 5.9% in after-hours trading. Berkshire, which held 13.29 million shares valued at around $4.07 billion as of March 31, has been a shareholder since 2012, when the stock traded at much lower levels. Despite having added to its position as recently as January, Berkshire has been a net seller of stocks for ten consecutive quarters and ended March with $347.7 billion in cash. Typically, the firm's smaller tech investments are managed by portfolio managers Todd Combs and Ted Weschler. Warren Buffett, 94, who has led Berkshire since 1965, is set to step down as CEO at the end of the year, while continuing as chairman. JPMorgan Securities underwrote the sale.

entries.title: VeriSign falls after Buffett's Berkshire sells $1.23 billion stock
entries.snippet: VeriSign's shares dropped over 7% on Tuesday following news that Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway sold nearly one-third of its stake in the company for $1.23 billion. The sale, involving 4.3 million shares at $285 each (a 6.9% discount), reduced Berkshire’s stake from 14.2% to 9.6%. An additional 515,032 shares may be sold to meet demand. This move aimed to bring the stake below the 10% regulatory threshold. Berkshire’s sale comes after a substantial long-term investment in VeriSign, which began in 2012 and had grown in value as the shares surged more than six-fold. Notably, further sales are restricted by a 365-day lock-up agreement. Analysts anticipate short-term market weakness but maintain a positive outlook focused on strong domain growth. At the end of March, Berkshire held $347.7 billion in cash, and updated figures are expected with its upcoming Q2 results.

entries.title: Berkshire Hathaway Just Bought $4 Million More of This Stock
entries.snippet:
Berkshire Hathaway has increased its investment in Verisign by purchasing approximately $4 million worth of shares, totaling around 20,000 shares at an average price of $205 each, as per a recent SEC Form 4 filing. With this move, Berkshire's total stake in Verisign has grown to 13.3 million shares, equating to about 14% of the company and valued around $2.7 billion. These recent buys continue a trend that began in mid-December, marking Berkshire's return to Verisign after a lengthy hiatus since 2014.

The buying activity may be attributed to Berkshire investment managers Ted Weschler or Todd Combs, who each manage about 10% of the firm’s $300 billion equity portfolio, with smaller individual stock holdings typically under $3 billion. Berkshire has now purchased shares for 12 consecutive trading days, although some transactions have been modest — such as 1,600 shares bought on a recent Tuesday.

Following the news, Verisign shares rose 2.1% to $210 in premarket trading, while Berkshire Hathaway shares increased 0.6% to $456.30.

entries.title: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway offloaded Apple shares again in second quarter
entries.snippet:
Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway resumed selling Apple shares in Q2 2025, offloading 20 million shares valued at over $4 billion, reducing its holdings to 280 million shares worth $57.4 billion. Despite these reductions, Apple still represents about 20% of Berkshire’s $268 billion stock portfolio. Buffett has been locking in profits from the Apple investment made in 2016, citing overvaluation and reduced growth as reasons for the sale. The timing proved challenging due to Apple’s stock volatility amid U.S.-China trade tensions, though shares recently rebounded 12% following a U.S. investment pledge by CEO Tim Cook.

Apple's sale formed the bulk of Berkshire’s $6.9 billion in equity divestments this quarter, which also included exiting T-Mobile and reducing holdings in Bank of America. The moves contributed to a $4.2 billion investment gain. Concurrently, Berkshire invested $3.9 billion in other equities, boosting stakes in Chevron, Domino’s Pizza, and Constellation Brands. It also added shares in Lennar, DR Horton, Nucor, and a $1.6 billion stake in insurer UnitedHealth, which rebounded 10% after the disclosure despite facing significant regulatory scrutiny and executive turnover.

entries.snippet: In the third quarter of 2024, Berkshire Hathaway sold 100 million shares of Apple, reducing its stake by 25% to 300 million shares. This follows a nearly 50% reduction in the second quarter, cutting the investment down from its peak of 905 million shares at the start of the year. The decision appears to be driven by Apple’s high valuation—trading at 30 times expected earnings—and a strategic rebalancing of Berkshire's portfolio, where Apple had previously comprised about 45%. Despite the sales, Apple remains Berkshire’s largest equity holding, now worth approximately $67 billion, accounting for under 25% of its $300 billion portfolio. The Apple shares were originally purchased at about $35 each between 2016 and 2018, and with the stock closing at $222.91 on the last trading day of the quarter, Berkshire has realized massive gains, estimated between $15 to $20 billion on the Apple sales alone. Cumulatively in 2024, the company reported $76.5 billion in investment gains, mostly from Apple. CEO Warren Buffett previously indicated Apple would likely remain Berkshire’s largest holding by year-end.

entries.title: Berkshire May Have Left $50 Billion on Table. Apple Is Why.
entries.snippet:
Warren Buffett’s decision to sell a significant portion of Apple stock may have cost Berkshire Hathaway approximately $50 billion in unrealized gains, according to Barron’s. Between 2016 and 2018, Berkshire acquired around 1 billion shares of Apple at an average price of $35. Most of the holding was sold in 2024 and 2025 at an estimated average price of $185, significantly below Apple’s current price of $262.24. By June 30, 2025, Berkshire’s Apple holdings had fallen to 280 million shares from 906 million at the end of 2023.

The sale generated roughly $96 billion in pretax gains but also resulted in nearly $20 billion in corporate income tax, lowering net proceeds to around $155 per share. Buffett cited concern over higher corporate taxes and the large size of the Apple stake as reasons for the sale. Some speculate he also aimed to strengthen Berkshire’s cash position, which stood at over $330 billion mid-2025, ahead of his retirement.

Apple was previously described by Buffett as a “pillar” of Berkshire’s value, suggesting it would be a long-term holding. The Apple sale, along with similar moves involving Bank of America, appears to have negatively impacted Berkshire’s performance, with its stock up 9% in 2025 versus the S&P 500’s 16%.

entries.title: Berkshire after Buffett: can any stockpicker follow the Oracle?
entries.snippet:
This Financial Times article examines the future of Berkshire Hathaway's investment strategy in a post-Warren Buffett era, focusing on the two successors likely to manage its $354 billion portfolio: Ted Weschler and Todd Combs. With the passing of Charlie Munger and Buffett nearing retirement at age 93, scrutiny has intensified over whether the duo can uphold the "Oracle of Omaha’s" extraordinary legacy.

Combs and Weschler, both former hedge fund managers, shared Buffett's value-oriented approach and his intense research habits. They made notable early investments—including in Visa, Mastercard, and DaVita—but recently have underperformed the S&P 500, trailing it in seven of the past ten years. Their average annual return of 7.8% lags behind both Buffett’s 10.2% and the index’s 12%. However, they initiated Berkshire’s hugely successful Apple investment, one of its best recent trades.

Their flexibility and autonomy, coupled with the company's “permanent capital” from insurance float and vast cash reserves, offer structural advantages. Still, they face challenges due to their massive portfolio size and the difficulty of finding high-return opportunities on such a scale.

Investors remain cautiously optimistic, acknowledging their skills but anxious for more transparency as they prepare to step into Buffett’s shoes.

entries.title: Berkshire reveals new $4.3 billion Alphabet stake, sells more Apple
entries.snippet:
Berkshire Hathaway revealed a new $4.3 billion investment in Alphabet, the parent company of Google, marking it as the firm's tenth-largest U.S. stock holding. This marks a notable move considering Warren Buffett's historical hesitance toward technology investments. Simultaneously, Berkshire continued to decrease its holdings in Apple, cutting its shares from 280 million to 238.2 million, and has now sold nearly three-quarters of its peak position of over 900 million shares. Despite the reduction, Apple remains its largest holding at $60.7 billion.

In its SEC filing covering the quarter ending September 30, Berkshire disclosed U.S.-listed stock holdings totaling $283.2 billion. The company also sold 6% of its Bank of America shares and exited its stake in homebuilder DR Horton, while purchasing additional shares in companies such as Chubb and Domino's Pizza. With $12.5 billion in stock sales and $6.4 billion in purchases for the quarter, Berkshire continues to be a net seller for the twelfth consecutive quarter. Its cash reserves have reached a record $381.7 billion.

This update comes as Warren Buffett prepares to step down after 60 years, handing over leadership to Vice Chairman Greg Abel on January 1, 2026.

entries.title: Warren Buffett hails Tim Cook for making Berkshire more money than he has — after selling two-thirds of his Apple stake
entries.snippet: At Berkshire Hathaway's 2025 annual meeting, Warren Buffett praised Apple CEO Tim Cook, calling him a "one-of-a-kind leader" and crediting him for significantly increasing Berkshire's wealth. Buffett noted that although Berkshire invested around $35 billion in Apple from 2016 to 2018, its value had risen to $173 billion by the end of 2023, largely due to Cook's leadership. Despite selling approximately two-thirds of its Apple holdings in 2024, retaining 300 million shares worth around $62 billion, Buffett lauded Cook's unmatched ability to grow the company. He highlighted that while Steve Jobs uniquely created Apple, only Cook could have developed it to its current stature. Under Cook’s leadership since 2011, Apple’s stock rose from under $15 to $205, elevating the company’s market capitalization to over $3 trillion.

entries.title: Buffett's Berkshire sells one-third of VeriSign stake for $1.23 billion
entries.snippet: Berkshire Hathaway has sold approximately one-third of its stake in VeriSign, an internet infrastructure and domain name registry company, for $1.23 billion. The sale involved 4.3 million shares at $285 each, reducing Berkshire's ownership from 14.2% to 9.6%. VeriSign noted the sale was intended to reduce Berkshire's stake below the 10% threshold, which triggers regulatory obligations. The price per share reflected a 6.9% discount from VeriSign’s last closing price of $305.98, and the stock dropped 5.9% in after-hours trading. Berkshire, which held 13.29 million shares valued at around $4.07 billion as of March 31, has been a shareholder since 2012, when the stock traded at much lower levels. Despite having added to its position as recently as January, Berkshire has been a net seller of stocks for ten consecutive quarters and ended March with $347.7 billion in cash. Typically, the firm's smaller tech investments are managed by portfolio managers Todd Combs and Ted Weschler. Warren Buffett, 94, who has led Berkshire since 1965, is set to step down as CEO at the end of the year, while continuing as chairman. JPMorgan Securities underwrote the sale.

entries.title: Why Did Berkshire Hathaway Invest in StoneCo Ltd.?
entries.snippet:
In October 2018, Berkshire Hathaway, led by Warren Buffett, made a significant investment in StoneCo Ltd., a Brazilian fintech company. This move sparked considerable interest due to Berkshire's reputation for investing in established, stable companies. StoneCo, based in São Paulo with headquarters in the Cayman Islands, offers a cloud-based platform to support digital payments, primarily targeting small- and medium-sized businesses in Brazil. It experienced rapid growth, reaching over four million customers by 2024 and capturing an increasing share of Brazil's payment processing market.

StoneCo was founded in 2012 by André Street and Eduardo Pontes, following their exit from a previous payments firm. It launched a successful IPO in 2018, raising its valuation to $6.1 billion. Berkshire Hathaway bought over 14 million shares at IPO, representing an 11.3% stake, despite Buffett’s usual skepticism of IPOs—this investment was attributed to his associate Todd Combs.

The company attracted other major investors, including Ant Financial and 3G Capital founders. However, StoneCo’s market capitalization saw a significant decline from a peak of $25.86 billion in 2020 to $2.39 billion by early 2025. Berkshire Hathaway exited its investment in early 2024.

entries.title: Buffett Is Out Of This Fintech Stock, But Now It's Back In A Buy Zone
entries.snippet:
StoneCo (STNE), a Brazil-based fintech company, is back in focus for investors as it reenters a buy zone following recent positive momentum. The stock reclaimed its 50-day moving average and formed a cup-with-handle pattern, clearing a buy point at $16. After a brief pullback, it remains within the 5% buy range, signaling potential for further gains. StoneCo's recent rally was fueled by strong second-quarter results, reporting 46% earnings growth to $0.41 per share and a 24% revenue increase to $644.4 million. This marked an acceleration from the prior quarter’s 21% earnings growth and 6% sales increase.

Once boosted to an all-time high of $95.12 in 2021 by Warren Buffett’s investment through Berkshire Hathaway, the stock later plummeted to $6.81 by May 2022 following Buffett’s divestment in 2023. However, it is now showing a robust recovery. StoneCo ranks first in its sector and holds a strong IBD Composite Rating of 97, with a 96 EPS Rating and increased institutional buying. Analysts forecast a 39% profit surge in 2025 and a 17% rise in 2026, supporting the stock’s renewed attractiveness to growth-focused investors.

entries.title: Warren Buffett invests $6bn in Japan's five biggest trading houses
entries.snippet: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway has made a $6 billion investment in Japan's five largest trading houses—Mitsubishi Corp, Mitsui & Co, Itochu Corp, Sumitomo Corp, and Marubeni Corp—marking a significant diversification beyond the US. The firm took a 5% stake in each company through its subsidiary, National Indemnity, and could potentially increase holdings to 9.9%. This move comes as a surprise, with analysts noting the typical conservatism in Buffett's investment strategy. However, the low valuations of the trading houses, whose shares had dipped during the pandemic, may have been an attractive factor. These "sogo shosha" play a crucial role in the Japanese economy, spanning industries from food imports to manufacturing and global joint ventures. The announcement boosted shares in all five companies, reflecting market approval. The investment strategy aligns with Buffett's aim to reduce Berkshire Hathaway's reliance on the US economy, which experienced steep contraction amid the COVID-19 crisis. It also follows a $4 billion yen bond issuance by Berkshire in 2019, signaling prior interest in Japanese financial markets. This move comes amid financial challenges at Berkshire’s US-based businesses, including massive layoffs and a $10 billion writedown at Precision Castparts.

entries.title: Berkshire Hathaway raises new CEO Abel's salary to $25 million
entries.snippet: Berkshire Hathaway announced it has increased the salary of its new CEO, Greg Abel, to $25 million for 2026—a significant rise compared to the $100,000 annual salary that long-time predecessor Warren Buffett drew for over 40 years. Abel, 63, officially took over as CEO on January 1, after serving eight years as vice chairman overseeing the company's non-insurance operations. His previous compensation included $21 million in 2024, $20 million in 2023, and $19 million (including a $3 million bonus) in 2022, matching the compensation of Vice Chairman Ajit Jain, who is responsible for the insurance portfolio. Abel also holds approximately $171 million in Berkshire stock and sold his 1% stake in Berkshire Hathaway Energy for $870 million in 2022. Despite stepping down as CEO, Warren Buffett, 95, remains Berkshire’s chairman after transforming the company into a $1 trillion conglomerate over six decades, owning businesses like Geico, BNSF Railway, and others. Berkshire has long taken a unique approach to executive compensation, diverging from other major public firms.

entries.title: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway successor to be paid $25m
entries.snippet:
Greg Abel has officially taken over as Berkshire Hathaway’s CEO from Warren Buffett and will receive a $25 million annual salary, a significant increase from Buffett’s long-standing $100,000 salary. Previously, Abel served as vice chairman overseeing Berkshire’s non-insurance operations, earning $21 million in 2024. Buffett, now 95, remains chairman of the company, which he led for over 60 years, transforming it into a $1 trillion conglomerate with nearly 200 subsidiaries across various industries including insurance, railroads, energy, and manufacturing. 

Buffett, still holding 36.4% of Berkshire’s Class A shares and a $150 billion net worth, has historically advocated for reasonable executive pay tied to performance, criticizing excessive compensation for average managers. In past comments, Buffett noted a preference for successors who are already wealthy and therefore not driven purely by financial gain. Abel owns $171 million in Berkshire stock and previously sold a 1% stake in Berkshire Hathaway Energy to the company for $870 million. Buffett has also spoken out against federal rules requiring pay comparisons between CEOs and average workers, arguing they foster unhealthy envy among executives.

entries.title: Berkshire Hathaway's new CEO has a much higher salary than Warren Buffett did
entries.snippet:
Greg Abel, the new CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, is receiving an annual salary of $25 million, significantly higher than Warren Buffett's long-standing $100,000 salary. Abel officially assumed the CEO role on January 1, following Buffett's retirement at the age of 95 after 55 years leading the company. The compensation was disclosed in a filing with the SEC and reflects a raise from the $21 million Abel earned the previous year. In contrast, the average CEO compensation for S&P 500 companies in 2024 was $18.9 million.

Buffett, who remains the company's chairman, spent decades setting compensation for executives, including Abel. He had previously identified Abel as his successor and praised his leadership of Berkshire Hathaway Energy, one of the company's key subsidiaries. Abel, 62, has been Berkshire’s Vice Chair of non-insurance operations since 2018 and is expected to uphold the firm’s investment philosophy while employing a more hands-on leadership style.

parts:
financeturn3finance0

### What “Buffett buying tech” really means
Over the last ~20 years, the headline “Warren Buffett buys tech” is mostly shorthand for **Berkshire Hathaway’s public-equity portfolio** (disclosed quarterly via **SEC (Securities and Exchange Commission) Form 13F** filings) shifting from *near-avoidance* of tech to *selective concentration*—with **Apple** becoming the defining position. Buffett has repeatedly framed Apple as *not a typical tech bet*, and in 2023 said it was a better business than any other Berkshire holding. citeturn4search3

---

## The arc in 3 phases

### 1) First modern “big tech” attempt: IBM (and why it failed)
**IBM (2011 → exited by 2018)** was Buffett-era Berkshire’s first large, explicit “technology” purchase:
- Berkshire began buying IBM in **March 2011** and built a roughly **$10.7B** position (about **64M shares**) disclosed publicly in November 2011. citeturn2search0  
- Over time, the thesis eroded; Berkshire **cut the IBM stake heavily** (e.g., a large reduction disclosed in 2017). citeturn2search5  
- By 2018, Buffett said Berkshire had effectively **zero** IBM shares. citeturn2search13  

**Interpretation:** IBM is the “why Buffett feared tech” case study. The risk wasn’t that IBM was unprofitable; it’s that in enterprise tech, **competitive position can decay faster than accounting statements reveal** (platform shifts like cloud/services, changing buyer preferences, and the difficulty of separating durable customer lock-in from inertia).

---

### 2) The breakthrough: Apple (the “tech” holding treated as consumer ecosystem)
**Apple (first bought 2016; built huge through 2018; trimmed heavily 2024–2025)**:
- Berkshire revealed an initial Apple stake in **Q1 2016** (about **9.8M shares**, ~**$1B** at the time). citeturn0search0  
- Buffett later publicly leaned in—saying Berkshire had more than doubled its Apple stake by early 2017. citeturn2search14  
- By 2023, Buffett explicitly called Apple the best business in Berkshire’s portfolio. citeturn4search3  
- Then, Berkshire **reduced Apple materially in 2024 and continued trimming in 2025** (concentration, valuation/tax positioning, and cash build all show up in contemporaneous reporting). citeturn1news42turn2news31  

**Why Apple fit Buffett-style investing (despite “tech”):**
- **Ecosystem switching costs** + brand loyalty = unusually durable demand versus typical hardware cycles.
- **Massive cash generation + buybacks**: buybacks were effectively Berkshire “owning more of Apple over time” even without buying new shares.
- **Predictability of consumer behavior** (vs forecasting which enterprise stack wins).

In short: **Buffett didn’t become a “tech investor”; he became willing to own a dominant consumer ecosystem that happens to use technology.**

---

### 3) Post-Apple: selective, often smaller, and sometimes event-driven tech exposure
From ~2019 onward, Berkshire’s tech purchases look like **a barbell**:
- a few “moat/tollbooth” compounders, and  
- smaller, more experimental positions (often attributed to Berkshire’s other portfolio managers rather than Buffett personally).

Key examples:

**HP (2022– ) — “value tech” / capital return story**  
Berkshire disclosed buying nearly **121M shares** (~**11.4% stake**, ~**$4.2B**). citeturn0search2  
Interpretation: not “innovation upside,” but a **cash-flow + buyback + valuation** bet in a mature hardware business.

**TSMC (2022 → mostly sold quickly) — fundamentals vs geopolitics**  
Berkshire bought **>$4.1B** of TSMC shares (July–Sept 2022) then sold **~86%** by year-end; Buffett cited **geopolitics** as a consideration. citeturn0search7  
Interpretation: even when the business quality is elite, **non-business risk can dominate** position sizing/holding period.

**Amazon (2019) — platform admiration, small position, likely “lieutenants”**  
Berkshire revealed an ~**$861M** Amazon stake and Buffett indicated it was bought by Combs/Weschler. citeturn1search9turn1search13  
Interpretation: Berkshire liked the business; the modest size signals either **valuation discomfort** or **circle-of-competence caution**.

**Snowflake (2020 → later exited) — rare IPO exposure**  
Berkshire disclosed a stake around the IPO period in 2020, widely read as a Combs/Weschler-style growth position, later sold out. citeturn1search10turn1search14  
Interpretation: Berkshire experimented with high-growth cloud software—but the later exit suggests it didn’t become a “core Berkshire kind of holding.”

**VeriSign (owned since 2012; trimmed 2025) — classic “tollbooth tech”**  
In 2025 Berkshire sold ~one-third of its VeriSign stake to get below the **10%** threshold (regulatory/filing implications). citeturn1search7  
Interpretation: this is arguably *more Buffett-like than most tech*: a quasi-infrastructure business with recurring economics.

**Activision Blizzard (merger arb) — not really “tech conviction”**  
Reuters described Berkshire cutting most of the position before a key Microsoft merger ruling. citeturn5search3  
Interpretation: primarily **deal/price mechanics**, not a long-horizon tech thesis.

**Alphabet / Google parent (new stake disclosed 2025) — notable late-cycle entrance**  
Berkshire disclosed a new **$4.3B** Alphabet position in 2025. citeturn4news41  
Interpretation: this looks like Berkshire expanding its “acceptable tech” set toward **cash-rich platforms**—especially as leadership responsibilities shift.

---

## The pattern: Buffett-style investing applied to a narrow subset of “tech”
Across winners and losers, Berkshire’s tech purchases cluster around businesses that look like one (or more) of these:

1) **Consumer ecosystem / habit-forming product** (Apple)  
2) **Infrastructure tollbooth** (VeriSign; arguably parts of the semiconductor supply chain like TSMC, though geopolitics intervened)  
3) **Mature cash-flow + buybacks** (HP)  
4) **Event-driven / special situations** (Activision)  
5) **Manager-driven exploratory growth** (Snowflake; some fintech-like bets)

And IBM shows the “anti-pattern”: a legacy enterprise incumbent where **the moat was harder to verify than the financials implied**.

---

## Forward-looking implication (still consistent with the last 20 years)
With Greg Abel taking over as CEO on **Jan 1, 2026** (Buffett remaining chairman), it’s plausible that Berkshire’s future “tech” purchases skew more toward the Combs/Weschler style—**more names, smaller positions, still value-aware**—while Apple remains the template for what a “Berkshire-grade tech investment” looks like. citeturn6news19

items.title: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway offloaded Apple shares again in second quarter
items.snippet:
Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway resumed selling Apple shares in Q2 2025, offloading 20 million shares valued at over $4 billion, reducing its holdings to 280 million shares worth $57.4 billion. Despite these reductions, Apple still represents about 20% of Berkshire’s $268 billion stock portfolio. Buffett has been locking in profits from the Apple investment made in 2016, citing overvaluation and reduced growth as reasons for the sale. The timing proved challenging due to Apple’s stock volatility amid U.S.-China trade tensions, though shares recently rebounded 12% following a U.S. investment pledge by CEO Tim Cook.

Apple's sale formed the bulk of Berkshire’s $6.9 billion in equity divestments this quarter, which also included exiting T-Mobile and reducing holdings in Bank of America. The moves contributed to a $4.2 billion investment gain. Concurrently, Berkshire invested $3.9 billion in other equities, boosting stakes in Chevron, Domino’s Pizza, and Constellation Brands. It also added shares in Lennar, DR Horton, Nucor, and a $1.6 billion stake in insurer UnitedHealth, which rebounded 10% after the disclosure despite facing significant regulatory scrutiny and executive turnover.

supporting_websites.title: Berkshire May Have Left $50 Billion on Table. Apple Is Why.
supporting_websites.snippet:
Warren Buffett’s decision to sell a significant portion of Apple stock may have cost Berkshire Hathaway approximately $50 billion in unrealized gains, according to Barron’s. Between 2016 and 2018, Berkshire acquired around 1 billion shares of Apple at an average price of $35. Most of the holding was sold in 2024 and 2025 at an estimated average price of $185, significantly below Apple’s current price of $262.24. By June 30, 2025, Berkshire’s Apple holdings had fallen to 280 million shares from 906 million at the end of 2023.

The sale generated roughly $96 billion in pretax gains but also resulted in nearly $20 billion in corporate income tax, lowering net proceeds to around $155 per share. Buffett cited concern over higher corporate taxes and the large size of the Apple stake as reasons for the sale. Some speculate he also aimed to strengthen Berkshire’s cash position, which stood at over $330 billion mid-2025, ahead of his retirement.

Apple was previously described by Buffett as a “pillar” of Berkshire’s value, suggesting it would be a long-term holding. The Apple sale, along with similar moves involving Bank of America, appears to have negatively impacted Berkshire’s performance, with its stock up 9% in 2025 versus the S&P 500’s 16%.

items.title: Buffett's Berkshire sells one-third of VeriSign stake for $1.23 billion
items.snippet: Berkshire Hathaway has sold approximately one-third of its stake in VeriSign, an internet infrastructure and domain name registry company, for $1.23 billion. The sale involved 4.3 million shares at $285 each, reducing Berkshire's ownership from 14.2% to 9.6%. VeriSign noted the sale was intended to reduce Berkshire's stake below the 10% threshold, which triggers regulatory obligations. The price per share reflected a 6.9% discount from VeriSign’s last closing price of $305.98, and the stock dropped 5.9% in after-hours trading. Berkshire, which held 13.29 million shares valued at around $4.07 billion as of March 31, has been a shareholder since 2012, when the stock traded at much lower levels. Despite having added to its position as recently as January, Berkshire has been a net seller of stocks for ten consecutive quarters and ended March with $347.7 billion in cash. Typically, the firm's smaller tech investments are managed by portfolio managers Todd Combs and Ted Weschler. Warren Buffett, 94, who has led Berkshire since 1965, is set to step down as CEO at the end of the year, while continuing as chairman. JPMorgan Securities underwrote the sale.

items.title: Berkshire reveals new $4.3 billion Alphabet stake, sells more Apple
items.snippet:
Berkshire Hathaway revealed a new $4.3 billion investment in Alphabet, the parent company of Google, marking it as the firm's tenth-largest U.S. stock holding. This marks a notable move considering Warren Buffett's historical hesitance toward technology investments. Simultaneously, Berkshire continued to decrease its holdings in Apple, cutting its shares from 280 million to 238.2 million, and has now sold nearly three-quarters of its peak position of over 900 million shares. Despite the reduction, Apple remains its largest holding at $60.7 billion.

In its SEC filing covering the quarter ending September 30, Berkshire disclosed U.S.-listed stock holdings totaling $283.2 billion. The company also sold 6% of its Bank of America shares and exited its stake in homebuilder DR Horton, while purchasing additional shares in companies such as Chubb and Domino's Pizza. With $12.5 billion in stock sales and $6.4 billion in purchases for the quarter, Berkshire continues to be a net seller for the twelfth consecutive quarter. Its cash reserves have reached a record $381.7 billion.

This update comes as Warren Buffett prepares to step down after 60 years, handing over leadership to Vice Chairman Greg Abel on January 1, 2026.

items.title: Berkshire Hathaway raises new CEO Abel's salary to $25 million
items.snippet: Berkshire Hathaway announced it has increased the salary of its new CEO, Greg Abel, to $25 million for 2026—a significant rise compared to the $100,000 annual salary that long-time predecessor Warren Buffett drew for over 40 years. Abel, 63, officially took over as CEO on January 1, after serving eight years as vice chairman overseeing the company's non-insurance operations. His previous compensation included $21 million in 2024, $20 million in 2023, and $19 million (including a $3 million bonus) in 2022, matching the compensation of Vice Chairman Ajit Jain, who is responsible for the insurance portfolio. Abel also holds approximately $171 million in Berkshire stock and sold his 1% stake in Berkshire Hathaway Energy for $870 million in 2022. Despite stepping down as CEO, Warren Buffett, 95, remains Berkshire’s chairman after transforming the company into a $1 trillion conglomerate over six decades, owning businesses like Geico, BNSF Railway, and others. Berkshire has long taken a unique approach to executive compensation, diverging from other major public firms.
